abstract.p: Theodore Stroup letter comments on August 4 article on consideration by US Army of expanded role for National Guard Combat units

block.p: ''Army Weighs an Expanded Role for National Guard Combat Units'' (front page, Aug. 4) properly shows the strategic relevance of the guard and reserve force.
''Army Weighs an Expanded Role for National Guard Combat Units'' (front page, Aug. 4) properly shows the strategic relevance of the guard and reserve force.

The plan, which will probably be unveiled in a month, demonstrates the Army's increasing reliance on its reserve components. As a former deputy chief of staff for personnel, I know that the plan takes into account that 55 percent of all soldiers are in the Army National Guard and the Army Reserve.

The dialogue within the Army on how best to employ all its soldiers was the necessary first step before the plan could be revised. The second step was to recognize formally the superb job and professionalism of soldiers in the National Guard and the Army Reserve. The 49th Armored Division, cited in your article, is the latest example.
The writer, a retired lieutenant general, is vice president for education, Assn. of the United States Army.
